message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are classic for Paget disease of the breast, which is a rare form of breast cancer that begins in the ducts of the breast before spreading to the skin of the nipple and areola. Inflammatory breast cancer would present with more diffuse erythema and edema involving the entire breast, and mastitis or breast abscess would show signs of infection, such as fever and localized tenderness. The patient’s family history of endometrial cancer is not relevant to her breast symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the vesicles and ulceration on the nipple, are suggestive of Paget disease of the breast. Inflammatory breast cancer usually presents with redness and swelling of the breast. Mastitis and breast abscess would present with localized erythema and tenderness, and there are no breast masses or dimpling in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Paget disease of the breast, which is characterized by an itchy rash and ulceration on the nipple. Inflammatory breast cancer will have breast masses, dimpling, or lymphadenopathy. Mastitis and breast abscess will have redness, warmth, and tenderness in the affected breast. The patient’s sister’s endometrial cancer is not related to this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation of a weeping, ulcerated lesion involving the nipple-areolar complex with no breast masses or axillary lymphadenopathy is most consistent with Paget disease of the breast. Inflammatory breast cancer usually presents with swelling, redness, and warmth of the breast while mastitis and breast abscesses typically present with tenderness, erythema, and warmth of the affected breast.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Paget disease of the breast presents with a rash on the nipple that evolves into a painful ulcer with discharge. Inflammatory breast cancer presents with rapid onset of erythema, edema, warmth, and skin thickening. Mastitis presents with fever, flu-like symptoms, and localized breast tenderness. Breast abscess presents with a fluctuant mass and fever.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The itchy rash on the nipple that became an ulcer with yellow, watery discharge and occasionally blood-tinged suggests Paget disease of the breast. Inflammatory breast cancer would present with breast masses, skin thickening, and erythema. Mastitis and breast abscess involve localized breast pain, fever, and breast masses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the rash on the nipple and areola, painful ulcer, and discharge, suggest the most likely diagnosis is Paget disease of the breast. Inflammatory breast cancer usually presents with rapid onset, redness and swelling of the entire breast and peau d'orange appearance. Mastitis and breast abscess typically present with localized redness, swelling, and tenderness of the breast, with possible fever and chills.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described, including a weeping, ulcerated lesion on the nipple and areola, suggest Paget disease of the breast, which is a rare type of breast cancer that affects the skin of the nipple and areola. Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with redness and swelling of the breast, along with other symptoms, such as pain and warmth. Mastitis and breast abscess typically present with fever, breast swelling, and tenderness, along with other symptoms such as flu-like symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of a weeping, ulcerated lesion involving the entire nipple-areolar complex suggest Paget disease of the breast, which is a rare type of breast cancer. Inflammatory breast cancer may present with similar symptoms but would have associated breast masses, dimpling, or axillary lymphadenopathy. Mastitis and breast abscess typically present with localized redness and swelling, fever, and purulent discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the rash beginning as small vesicles on the nipple and spreading to the areola, becoming an ulcer with yellow, watery discharge that is occasionally blood-tinged suggests Paget disease of the breast. Inflammatory breast cancer would present with redness, warmth, and swelling of the breast while mastitis and breast abscess would have more localized symptoms. The patient’s history of endometrial cancer in her sister is not relevant to the diagnosis of her breast condition.
